About

I’m a third-year PhD student in the Climate-Ocean-Atmosphere Program at Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego. I combine theory, observations, and computer simulations to study how the ocean flows and shapes the climate. My recent research has targeted the turbulent and wavy dynamics of the upper ocean at horizontal scales between 1-300 km. You can find more about me on my vitae.

Career

  • 2016

    NASA Earth and Space Science Graduate Fellow

  • Summer 2015

    Fellow of the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Program

  • September 2013

    Joined the Climate-Ocean-Atmosphere Program at Scripps, UC San Diego

  • July 2013

    Graduated with a MSc degree from University of Sao Paulo

  • February 2011

    Graduated with a BSc degree from University of Sao Paulo

Code

I strive to write high-quality, well-tested, and well-documented code. I’m an advocate of free software. All my codes are under version control, and I contribute to several open source projects. I’m core developer for pyqg, a pythonic pseudo-spectral code to solve the quasigeostrophic equations. Checkout my repositories on github, and ping me if you have any questions.

I’m a member of NumFOCUS (open code, better science), I agree with Lorena Barba, and I endorse the science code manifesto. I wrote the Open Science Graduate Student Manifesto .

Collaborators

I’m foturnate to work with very talented scientists. In the past couple of years, I have worked with

Bill Young, Sarah Gille, Teri Chereskin, Ian Grooms, Dimitris Menemenlis, Greg Chini, Ilson Silveira, Amit Tandon

Contact

Feel free to ping me if you have any questions, ideas, or complaints.

Publications

Coming up soon

  • Rocha, C. B., S. T. Gille, T. K. Chereskin, D. Menemenlis: “Seasonality of submesoscale dynamics in the Kuroshio Extension”, under review for GRL. (project repository).

  • Ardhuin, F., Gille, S. T., Menemenlis, D., Rocha, C. B., Rascle, N., Chapron, B., Gula, J., Molemaker, J.,: Small scale currents have large effects on ocean wave heights, under review for GRL.

  • Rocha, C. B. and W. R. Young: “Homogeneous quasigeostrophic turbulence driven by a uniform wind stress”, to be submitted to JFM.

  • Rocha, C. B., S. T. Gille and T. K. Chereskin: “Mesoscale to Submesoscale Upper-Ocean Spectra from AltiKa and a numerical simulation”, to be submitted to JGR.

  • T. Chereskin, S. T. Gille, Rocha, C. B.: “Wave-vortex decomposition in the California Current System, to be submitted to JPO.

Peer-reviewed

  • Rocha, C. B., T. Chereskin, S. T. Gille, and D. Menemenlis (2016): Mesoscale to submesoscale wavenumber spectra in Drake Passage, J. Phys. Oceanogr., 46, 601-620, doi:10.1175/JPO-D-15-0087.1. (preprint, data and codes).

  • Rocha, C. B., W. R. Young, and I. Grooms (2016): On Galerkin approximations for the surface-active quasigeostrophic equations, J. Phys. Oceanogr., 46, 125–139, doi:10.1175/JPO- D-15-0073.1 (pdf, arXiv, codes, algebra details, wordle)

  • Rocha, C. B., I. C. A. da Silveira, B. M. Castro, and J. A. M. Lima (2014), Vertical structure, energetics, and dynamics of the Brazil Current System at 22S–28S, J. Geophys. Res. Oceans, 119, 52–69, doi:10.1002/2013JC009143

  • Rocha, C. B., A. Tandon, I. C. A. da Silveira, and J. A. M. Lima (2013), Traditional quasi-geostrophic modes and surface quasi-geostrophic solutions in the Southwestern Atlantic, J. Geophys. Res. Oceans, 118, 2734–2745. doi:10.1002/jgrc.20214

The grey literature

  • Rocha, C. B., 2015: Coupled reduced equations for strongly stratified flows, Proceedings of the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Program, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA.
